name: React for Beginners
description: Learn the fundamentals of React and start building modern user interfaces
fullDescription: This beginner-friendly React course introduces you to the core concepts needed to build interactive web applications. You’ll learn how React works, how to create and reuse components, manage state and props, handle events, and build simple applications using modern React practices. No prior React experience is required, but basic JavaScript knowledge is recommended.

technicalContent.title: What is React?
technicalContent.content: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, primarily for single-page applications. It allows developers to create reusable UI components and efficiently update the UI when data changes using a virtual DOM.

technicalContent.title: Understanding JSX
technicalContent.content: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code inside JavaScript. It makes React components easier to read and write, while still being transformed into regular JavaScript under the hood.

technicalContent.title: Creating Your First React Component
technicalContent.content: Components are the building blocks of React applications. A component can be a function that returns JSX describing what should appear on the screen.

technicalContent.title: Props in React
technicalContent.content: Props (short for properties) are used to pass data from a parent component to a child component. They make components reusable and dynamic.

technicalContent.title: Using State with useState Hook
technicalContent.content: State allows components to manage and store data that can change over time. The useState hook is the most common way to add state to functional components.

technicalContent.title: Handling Events in React
technicalContent.content: React handles events similarly to DOM events but uses camelCase syntax. Event handlers are passed as functions and allow you to respond to user actions.

technicalContent.title: Rendering Lists in React
technicalContent.content: You can render lists in React by using JavaScript’s map() method. Each item in a list should have a unique key to help React optimize rendering.

technicalContent.title: Conditional Rendering
technicalContent.content: Conditional rendering allows you to display different UI elements based on certain conditions. This can be done using if statements, ternary operators, or logical && operators.

technicalContent.title: Controlled Components and Forms
technicalContent.content: In controlled components, form data is handled by React state. This gives you full control over form inputs and makes validation easier.

technicalContent.title: Introduction to useEffect
technicalContent.content: The useEffect hook lets you perform side effects in functional components, such as fetching data, updating the DOM, or setting up subscriptions.

mcqQuestions.question: What is React primarily used for?
mcqQuestions.explanation: React is a JavaScript library used to build user interfaces, especially for single-page applications.

mcqQuestions.question: What does JSX stand for?
mcqQuestions.explanation: JSX stands for JavaScript XML and allows writing HTML-like syntax in JavaScript.

mcqQuestions.question: Which hook is used to manage state in a functional component?
mcqQuestions.explanation: useState is the React hook used to add state to functional components.

mcqQuestions.question: How do you pass data to a component in React?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Props are used to pass data from parent components to child components.

mcqQuestions.question: What must be added to list items rendered using map()?
mcqQuestions.explanation: Each list item needs a unique key to help React identify elements efficiently.

mcqQuestions.question: Which syntax is used for event handlers in React?
mcqQuestions.explanation: React uses camelCase syntax for event handlers, such as onClick.

mcqQuestions.question: What does the useEffect hook handle?
mcqQuestions.explanation: useEffect is used to handle side effects like data fetching and subscriptions.

mcqQuestions.question: Which of the following is a controlled component?
options: An input managed by the DOM
An input managed by React state
mcqQuestions.explanation: A controlled component is one whose value is controlled by React state.

mcqQuestions.question: What is the virtual DOM?
options: A copy of the real DOM stored in memory
mcqQuestions.explanation: The virtual DOM is a lightweight in-memory representation of the real DOM used by React for efficient updates.

mcqQuestions.question: Which command is commonly used to create a new React app?
mcqQuestions.explanation: npx create-react-app is commonly used to quickly set up a new React project.
